newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada postpones anti-tobacco strategy release.
newsitem.headline: Canada postpones anti-tobacco strategy release.

text.p: Canadian Health Minister David Dingwall has postponed the announcement of new anti-tobacco measures, Health Canada announced Wednesday.
Dingwall had been expected to release details of his long-awaited anti-tobacco legislation at a news conference on Thursday. No new date was given.

While no reason was given for the postponement, the Ottawa Citizen reported on Wednesday that Canada's native leaders had been angered that it would be on the same day as a major report of the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples.
The Canadian media has speculated that among measures Dingwall will announce is a tax hike that would raise the price of cigarettes by 15 cents a pack.
Imperial Tobacco Ltd, a unit of Imasco Ltd controls about 65 percent of the Canadian cigarette market. Imasco is 40 percent owned by B.A.T. Industries Plc of Britain.
Another major player is Rothmans, Benson and Hedges Inc, owned 60 percent by Rothmans International, a unit of Rothmans International Plc, and 40 percent by Philip Morris Cos Inc.
A third player is RJR MacDonald is wholly owned by RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp unit R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International.
Dingwall later told Parliament that the announcement was postponed because "all the details are not finalized." -- Mark MacKinnon, Reuters Ottawa Bureau (613) 235-6745
